conclusion: To solve the problem, analyze the velocity-time graphs for Objects A and B to determine when they are farthest apart.

The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled A and B. Graph A starts at zero velocity, increases linearly to a maximum velocity, and then decreases linearly back to zero. Graph B starts at zero velocity, increases linearly to a maximum velocity, and then continues linearly beyond the maximum velocity.

premise: Graph A represents an object that starts, accelerates, and then decelerates back to zero velocity. Graph B represents an object that starts, accelerates, and then continues to move at a constant velocity beyond the maximum acceleration.
The distance of an object from its starting point is determined by the area under its velocity-time graph.
conclusion: For Graph A, the area under the curve is maximized when the object is at its maximum velocity. For Graph B, the area under the curve is maximized when the object is at its maximum velocity and continues to move at that velocity.

premise: For Graph A, the maximum distance occurs at the time when the object's velocity is at its peak. For Graph B, the maximum distance occurs at the time when the object's velocity is at its peak and continues to move at that velocity.
By comparing the times at which the maximum distances occur for both objects, we can determine when they are farthest apart.
The moment when both objects are farthest apart is when the distance from their starting point is maximized.
conclusion: This occurs at the time when the velocity of each object is at its peak and continues to move at that velocity for Object B.
The moment when both objects are farthest apart is at t = 3.
